newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia plans to host Tajik summit in Moscow.
newsitem.headline: Russia plans to host Tajik summit in Moscow.

text.p: Russia said on Tuesday it had invited Tajikistan President Imomali Rakhmonov and his Islamic opponent Said Abdullo Nuri to Moscow as part of efforts to restore peace in the war-ravaged former Soviet republic.
"An inter-Tajik summit will take place in Moscow and the date will be agreed once Mr Nuri has accepted the invitation," foreign ministry spokesman Gennady Tarasov told a regular news briefing.
On Monday Interfax news agency quoted Tajik government spokesman Zafar Saidov as saying the meeting, aimed at getting peace talks going again, could take place as early as this week.
"The government side hopes that this meeting (in Moscow) will speed up a resolution of the Tajik problem by peaceful political means," Interfax quoted Saidov as saying.
But a leading member of the Tajik opposition suggested that the proposed meeting might not go ahead at all.

"This meeting will probably not take place due to the intransigent attitude of President Rakhmonov," Ali Akbar Turajonzoda, deputy head of the Tajik united opposition, told Reuters by telephone from Tehran on Monday.
"The experts (from both sides) who gathered in Tehran on October 15 to 17 (to draw up a peace document for signing in Moscow) failed to work out the slightest compromise," he said.
He said the opposition was seeking the creation of a "council of national reconciliation" that would help govern the country during a transitional period lasting up to 18 months.
"During this transition period Rakhmonov, the government and parliament would stay in place, they would lose nothing and would continue to hold power," Turajonzoda said.
The opposition's eventual aim was free elections held probably under the auspices of the United Nations, he added.

Since winning its independence nearly six years ago Tajikistan has been battered by a civil war that has pitted pro-Moscow forces against Islamic revivalists and liberals whose leaders are now in exile in Afghanistan, Iran and Russia.
Tens of thousands died in the fighting and nearly a million were displaced in the "hot" civil war of 1992-93.
Russian frontier guards are helping the pro-Moscow government in Dushanbe to resist Islamic Tajik rebels based in neighbouring Afghanistan.
Earlier this month Moscow and Dushanbe, alarmed by the rise to power in Kabul of the hardline Islamic Taleban militia, agreed to tighten security along the Tajik-Afghan border.
